content.answer: Banabhatta, Xuanzang, and Harshacharita.

content.question: What changes do you find in the army at this time?

rubrics.title: Mentions the use of foot soldiers

content.answer: The army included elephants, cavalry, and foot soldiers.

content.question: What were the new administrative arrangements during this period?

rubrics.title: Mentions the division of the empire into provinces

content.answer: The empire was divided into provinces, each governed by officials, and local assemblies played a role in administration.

content.question: What do you think Arvind would have to do if he was acting as Samudragupta?
content.answer: Arvind would need to conquer territories, collect tribute, and maintain administration.

content.question: Do you think ordinary people would have read and understood the prashastis? Give reasons for your answer.
content.answer: Ordinary people likely did not read prashastis due to low literacy levels, the use of Sanskrit, and the purpose being to praise rulers.

content.question: If you had to make a genealogy for yourself, who are the people you would include in it? How many generations would you like to show? Make a chart and fill it.
content.answer: A chart including at least three generations of family members, organized logically.

content.question: How do you think wars affect the lives of ordinary people today?
content.answer: Wars cause displacement, economic hardship, and psychological stress for ordinary people.

content.question: Make a list of the chapters in which you find mention of metal working. What are the metal objects mentioned or shown in those chapters?
content.answer: The chapters that mention metal working include Chapter 4: 'In the Earliest Cities', Chapter 7: 'New Questions and Ideas', and Chapter 9: 'Traders, Kings and Pilgrims'. The metal objects mentioned include tools, weapons, and ornaments.

content.question: Read the story on page 104. In what ways is the monkey king similar to or different from the kings you read about in Chapters 5 and 9?
content.answer: The monkey king is similar to the kings in Chapters 5 and 9 in terms of leadership and protection of his subjects. However, he differs in his selflessness and willingness to sacrifice for his subjects, unlike some human kings who were more concerned with power.

content.question: Find out more and tell a story from one of the epics.
content.answer: A story from the epic 'Mahabharata' is the tale of Arjuna's dilemma on the battlefield of Kurukshetra, where he is guided by Lord Krishna, who imparts the teachings of the Bhagavad Gita.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI

content.question: List some steps that can be taken to make buildings and monuments accessible to differently abled people.
content.answer: Some steps include installing ramps, elevators, tactile paving, audio guides, and braille signs. These modifications ensure that individuals with mobility, visual, or auditory impairments can access and enjoy these sites.

content.question: Try and list as many uses of paper as you can.

rubrics.title: Includes both common and uncommon uses

content.answer: Paper is used for writing, printing books, newspapers, packaging, crafting, making paper towels, and creating currency, among others.

content.question: If you could visit any one of the places described in this chapter, which would you choose and why?

rubrics.title: Provides a reason for the choice
Connects the choice to historical or personal interest

content.answer: I would choose to visit the Ajanta Caves because of their stunning ancient paintings and sculptures, which provide insight into the art and culture of ancient India.

worksheet.chapterName: The Earth in the Solar System

content.question: How does a planet differ from a star?
content.answer: A planet is a celestial body that orbits a star and does not produce its own light, while a star is a massive, luminous sphere of plasma that generates energy through nuclear fusion.

content.question: What is meant by the ‘Solar System’?
content.answer: The Solar System is a collection of celestial bodies, including the Sun, planets, moons, asteroids, comets, and meteoroids, that are bound by gravitational forces.

content.question: Name all the planets according to their distance from the sun.
content.answer: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune.

content.question: Why is the Earth called a unique planet?
content.answer: Earth is called a unique planet because it supports life, has abundant water, and a suitable atmosphere with oxygen.

content.question: Why do we see only one side of the moon always?
content.answer: We see only one side of the moon because it rotates on its axis at the same rate that it orbits Earth, a phenomenon known as synchronous rotation.

content.question: What is the Universe?
content.answer: The Universe is the vast space that contains all matter and energy, including galaxies, stars, planets, and all forms of life.

content.question:
You might have heard that people make human chains and run for world peace etc. You can also make a human solar system and run for fun. Follow these steps: 

Step 1: All children of your class can play this game. Assemble in a big hall or on a playground.

Step 2: Now draw 8 circles on the ground as shown in the figure drawn on the opposite page. Use a 5-metre long rope. Mark at every half a metre with a chalk or ink. Place a small nail to mark the centre. Now hold one end of the rope at the central position. Ask your friend to hold a chalk at the ½ metre mark and move around the nail holding rope and chalk together on the ground. You have drawn one circle just as you do on paper using a compass and a pencil. Draw other circles in the same manner.

Step 3: Prepare 10 placards. Name them as Sun, Moon, Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune.

Step 4: Select 10 children in the following order and give each one of them a placard. Order of placard distribution: The Sun - tallest, The moon - smallest; Mercury, Mars, Venus and Earth (almost equal heights); Neptune, Uranus, Saturn and Jupiter taller than the earlier four planets but smaller than the Sun. Now ask the children holding placards to take their places with the Sun in the centre in their orbits. Ask the child holding the moon placard to keep the hand of the child holding the earth placard always. Now your Solar System is almost ready to go into action. Now make everybody move slowly in the anti-clockwise direction. Your class has turned into a small human replica of the solar system. While moving on your orbit you can also turn around. For everybody the spin should be anti-clockwise except for Venus and Uranus who will make the spin in the clockwise direction.
content.answer: The activity involves drawing circles and organizing students as planets with placards. Ensure the correct order and movement as per instructions.

content.question: What is the true shape of the earth?
content.answer: The true shape of the earth is a geoid, which means it is slightly flattened at the poles and bulging at the equator.

content.question: What is a globe?
content.answer: A globe is a spherical model of Earth, representing its continents, oceans, and countries.

content.question: What is the latitudinal value of the Tropic of Cancer?
content.answer: The latitudinal value of the Tropic of Cancer is 23.5° North.

content.question: What are the three heat zones of the Earth?
content.answer: The three heat zones of the Earth are the Torrid Zone, Temperate Zones, and Frigid Zones. The Torrid Zone is the hottest, located between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn. The Temperate Zones lie between the Tropics and the Polar Circles, and the Frigid Zones are the coldest, near the poles.

content.question: What are parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude?
content.answer: Parallels of latitude are imaginary lines parallel to the Equator, used to measure degrees north or south. Meridians of longitude are imaginary lines that run from the North Pole to the South Pole, used to measure degrees east or west.

content.question: Why does the torrid zone receive maximum amount of heat?
content.answer: The Torrid Zone receives the maximum amount of heat because it is located around the Equator where the sun's rays strike the Earth most directly throughout the year.

content.question: Why is it 5.30 p.m. in India and 12.00 noon in London?
content.answer: It is 5.30 p.m. in India and 12.00 noon in London because India is 5 hours and 30 minutes ahead of Greenwich Mean Time (GMT), which is the time zone of London. This is due to the longitudinal difference between the two locations.

content.question: Draw a diagram of the globe showing the earth’s axis, the Equator, Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, Arctic Circle and Antarctic Circle.

rubrics.title: Accurate Placement of Arctic and Antarctic Circles

content.answer: The diagram should clearly show the earth's axis tilted at an angle, the Equator at 0°, Tropic of Cancer at 23.5°N, Tropic of Capricorn at 23.5°S, Arctic Circle at 66.5°N, and Antarctic Circle at 66.5°S.

content.question: Draw and cut out six circles of the same size (approx. 3 cm. radius) from cardboard. Mark diameters (NS, EW) and 23½° angles on each face of the circles as shown on the figure. Place the circles one on top of the other and stitch along the line NS. Now there are twelve semi-circles. Let one semi-circle represent 0° or Greenwich Meridian (Prime Meridian). The 6th semi-circle from it will be the 180° Meridian. Between the 0° and 180° there are 5 semi-circles on both sides which are West and East longitudes 30° apart. On two ends of the stapled line stick pins to represent the North and South Poles. A rubber band around the model touching the EW points will represent the Equator. Two rubber bands touching the 23½° points, South and North of the EW points will represent the tropics.

rubrics.title: Correct Size and Shape of Circles
Accurate Marking of Diameters and Angles
Correct Representation of Prime and 180° Meridians
Proper Placement of Rubber Bands for Equator and Tropics

content.answer: The model should consist of six circles with marked diameters and angles, assembled to show the Prime Meridian and 180° Meridian, with rubber bands representing the Equator and Tropics accurately.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

content.question: What is the angle of inclination of the earth’s axis with its orbital plane?
content.answer: The angle of inclination of the earth’s axis with its orbital plane is 66.5 degrees.

content.question: Define rotation and revolution.
content.answer: Rotation is the spinning of the Earth on its axis, causing day and night. Revolution is the Earth's movement around the Sun, taking approximately 365.25 days to complete.

content.question: What is a leap year?
content.answer: A leap year is a year that has 366 days, with an extra day added to the month of February, occurring every four years to account for the extra 0.25 days in the Earth's orbit around the Sun.

content.question: Differentiate between the Summer and Winter Solstice.
content.answer: The Summer Solstice occurs around June 21st and is the longest day of the year in the Northern Hemisphere. The Winter Solstice occurs around December 22nd and is the shortest day of the year in the Northern Hemisphere.

content.question: What is an equinox?
content.answer: An equinox is a day when the duration of day and night are approximately equal, occurring twice a year around March 21st and September 23rd.

content.question: Why does the Southern Hemisphere experience Winter and Summer Solstice at different times than that of the Northern Hemisphere?
content.answer: The Southern Hemisphere experiences Winter and Summer Solstice at different times than the Northern Hemisphere due to the tilt of the Earth's axis, which causes opposite seasons in the two hemispheres.

content.question: Why do the poles experience about six months day and six months night?
content.answer: The poles experience about six months of day and six months of night due to the tilt of the Earth's axis, which keeps the poles either in continuous sunlight or darkness as the Earth orbits the Sun.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

Direct rays of the sun fall on the equator on
Christmas is celebrated in summer in

worksheet.subject: Geography

content.question: Make a drawing to show the inclination of the earth.
content.answer: The drawing should accurately depict the Earth's tilt at approximately 23.5 degrees, with the axis correctly represented and labeled.

content.question: Record the timings of sunrise and sunset at your place taking help from your local newspaper on the 21st of each month. In which month are the days the shortest?
content.answer: The shortest day is typically around December 21st, which is the winter solstice.

content.question: Record the timings of sunrise and sunset at your place taking help from your local newspaper on the 21st of each month. In which months are the days and nights nearly equal?
content.answer: Days and nights are nearly equal during the equinoxes, around March 21st and September 23rd.

content.question: Draw different shapes of ellipses by placing two pins nearer and farther using the same loop of thread. Notice when the ellipse becomes circular.

rubrics.title: Correct Use of Pins and Thread

content.answer: The drawing should show various ellipses with different eccentricities, and indicate when the shape approaches a circle.

content.question: On any sunny day, take a straight stick that is one metre long. Find out a clean and level place on the ground. Place this stick into the ground where it casts a distinctive (sharp) shadow. Mark the tip of the shadow with a stone or a twig or by any other means. The first shadow mark is always towards the west. See after 15 minutes and mark the tip of the shadow again. By then it would have moved a few centimetres away. Now join the two points and you have an approximate east-west line. Stand with the first mark to your left and the second mark to your right you are now facing north. This fact is true everywhere on the earth because the earth rotates in west to east direction. An alternative method is more accurate but requires more time. Set up your shadow stick and mark the first shadow in the morning. Use a piece of string to draw a clean arc through this mark around the stick. At mid-day, the shadow will shrink or disappear. In the afternoon, it will lengthen again and at the point where it touches the arc, make a second mark. Draw a line through the two marks to get an accurate east-west line.
content.answer: The activity should result in an east-west line being drawn by joining the shadow marks, demonstrating the Earth's rotation from west to east.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

content.question: What are the four major domains of the earth?
content.answer: The four major domains of the earth are the Lithosphere, Hydrosphere, Atmosphere, and Biosphere.

content.question: Name the major continents of the earth.
content.answer: The major continents of the earth are Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia.

content.question: Name the two continents that lie entirely in the Southern Hemisphere.
content.answer: The two continents that lie entirely in the Southern Hemisphere are Australia and Antarctica.

content.question: Name the different layers of atmosphere.
content.answer: The different layers of the atmosphere are the Troposphere, Stratosphere, Mesosphere, Thermosphere, and Exosphere.

content.question: Why is the earth called the ‘blue planet’?
content.answer: The earth is called the ‘blue planet’ because over 70% of its surface is covered with water, giving it a blue appearance from space.

content.question: Why is the Northern Hemisphere called the Land Hemisphere?
content.answer: The Northern Hemisphere is called the Land Hemisphere because it contains the majority of the Earth's landmass, including most of Asia, Europe, North America, and Africa.

content.question: Why is the Biosphere important for living organisms?
content.answer: The Biosphere is important for living organisms because it is the global sum of all ecosystems, providing the necessary conditions for life, such as air, water, and nutrients.

content.question: Cut the outline of the continents from an outline map of the world and arrange them according to their decreasing sizes.
content.answer: Continents should be arranged as Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia.

content.question: Cut the outline of the continents from an outline map of the world and try to fit them together as a jig-saw puzzle.
content.answer: Continents should be fitted together to reflect the concept of Pangaea, showing how they might have once been connected.

content.question: Collect pictures of expeditions to the Himalayas. Write about the kind of equipment carried by the climbers for protection against sunshine, temperature and the lack of air.
content.answer: Climbers carry equipment such as insulated clothing, oxygen tanks, sunglasses, and sunscreen to protect against harsh weather conditions, low temperatures, and high altitude effects.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

content.question: On the outline map of the world, mark the following: Europe, Asia, Antarctica, South America, Australia, Indian Ocean, Pacific Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, Ural Mountains, and Isthmus of Panama.
content.answer: The student should accurately mark each of the specified continents, oceans, mountains, and isthmus on the provided world map outline.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

content.question: Name the major physical divisions of India.
content.answer: The major physical divisions of India are the Himalayas, the Northern Plains, the Peninsular Plateau, the Indian Desert, the Coastal Plains, and the Islands.

content.question: India shares its land boundaries with seven countries. Name them.
content.answer: India shares its land boundaries with Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Afghanistan.

content.question: Which two major rivers fall into the Arabian Sea?
content.answer: The two major rivers that fall into the Arabian Sea are the Narmada and the Tapi.

content.question: Name the delta formed by the Ganga and the Brahmaputra.
content.answer: The delta formed by the Ganga and the Brahmaputra is called the Sundarbans Delta.

questions.topic: States and Union Territories of India

content.question: How many States and Union Territories are there in India? Which states have a common capital?

rubrics.title: Correctly states the number of States and Union Territories
Identifies states with a common capital

content.answer: India has 28 States and 8 Union Territories. Punjab and Haryana have a common capital, which is Chandigarh.

content.question: Why do a large number of people live in the Northern plains?
content.answer: A large number of people live in the Northern plains because the region is fertile, has a favorable climate, and is well-irrigated, making it ideal for agriculture.

content.question: Why is Lakshadweep known as a coral island?

rubrics.title: Explains the formation of coral islands

content.answer: Lakshadweep is known as a coral island because it is formed from coral deposits.

content.question: On an outline map of India, mark the following: Tropic of Cancer, Standard Meridian of India, the state in which you live, Andaman Islands and Lakshadweep Islands, Western Ghats and Eastern Ghats.

rubrics.title: Correct Placement of Tropic of Cancer
Correct Placement of Standard Meridian of India
Correct Identification of Western and Eastern Ghats

content.answer: The Tropic of Cancer should be drawn approximately at 23.5°N latitude. The Standard Meridian of India is 82.5°E longitude. The student's state should be marked accurately based on their location. Andaman Islands should be marked in the Bay of Bengal, and Lakshadweep Islands in the Arabian Sea. Western Ghats should be marked along the western coast, and Eastern Ghats along the eastern coast of India.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Draw up a list of the different festivals celebrated in your locality. Which of these celebrations are shared by members of different regional and religious communities?
content.answer: Students should list festivals such as Diwali, Eid, Christmas, etc., and explain how these festivals are celebrated by different communities, reflecting India's cultural diversity.

content.question: What do you think living in India with its rich heritage of diversity adds to your life?
content.answer: Living in India enriches life by exposing individuals to various cultures, languages, and traditions, fostering a sense of inclusivity and understanding.

content.question: Do you think the term “unity in diversity” is an appropriate term to describe India? What do you think Nehru is trying to say about Indian unity in the sentence quoted above from his book The Discovery of India?
content.answer: The term 'unity in diversity' is apt for India as it signifies the coexistence of diverse cultures. Nehru emphasizes that despite differences, there is a fundamental unity in the Indian ethos.

content.question: Underline the line in the poem sung after the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, which according to you, reflects India’s essential unity.
content.answer: Students should identify a line that speaks to the collective spirit or shared struggle of Indians, highlighting unity.

content.question: Choose another region in India and do a similar study of the historical and geographical factors that influence the diversity found there. Are these historical and geographical factors connected to each other? How?
content.answer: Students should select a region like Kerala and discuss how its history and geography, such as trade routes and coastal location, contribute to its cultural diversity.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: List at least three different ways in which people in India pray. One of the possible answers has been provided for you already: Through singing a hymn.
content.answer: In addition to singing hymns, people in India pray through chanting mantras, performing rituals, and meditating.

content.question: List at least three different ways in which people in India get married.
content.answer: People in India get married through arranged marriages, love marriages, and traditional ceremonies like Hindu weddings or Nikah in Islam.

content.question: List at least three different ways in which people in India dress.
content.answer: People in India dress in sarees, dhotis, and salwar kameez, reflecting the country's diverse cultures.

content.question: List at least three different ways in which people in India greet each other.
content.answer: People in India greet each other with Namaste, Salaam, or by touching feet, depending on cultural practices.

content.question: List at least three different ways in which people in India cook rice.
content.answer: Rice in India is cooked as plain steamed rice, biryani, and pulao, showcasing various regional flavors.

content.question: Look at the map of India in an Atlas and locate Kerala and Ladakh. Can you list three ways in which the different geographical location of these two regions would influence the following? - The food people eat: - The clothes they wear: - The work they do:

rubrics.title: Provides specific examples for each influence

content.answer: Kerala, being a coastal region, has a diet rich in seafood and coconut-based dishes, while Ladakh, being a mountainous region, relies on barley, dairy, and meat. In terms of clothing, Kerala's warm climate leads to the use of light cotton clothes, whereas Ladakh's cold climate necessitates woolen garments. The work in Kerala is often related to agriculture and fishing, while in Ladakh, it is more focused on animal husbandry and tourism due to its terrain and climate.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Match the following statements in a way that challenges stereotypes.

pairs.left: Two surgeons were sitting down to lunch when one of them made a call on the mobile phone
pairs.right: to speak with her daughter who had just returned from school.

pairs.left: The boy who won the drawing competition went to the dias
pairs.right: on a wheelchair to collect his prize.

pairs.left: One of the fastest athletes in the world
She was not that well-off but had a dream
pairs.right: to become an astronaut which she did.

questions.answer:
1. Two surgeons were sitting down to lunch when one of them made a call on the mobile phone to speak with her daughter who had just returned from school.
2. The boy who won the drawing competition went to the dias on a wheelchair to collect his prize.
3. One of the fastest athletes in the world suffers from chronic asthma.
4. She was not that well-off but had a dream to become an astronaut which she did.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: How can the stereotype that girls are a burden on their parents affect the life of a daughter? Imagine this situation and list at least five different effects that this stereotype can have on the way daughters get treated in the house.
content.answer: The stereotype that girls are a burden can lead to daughters being undervalued and neglected in various ways. This can include being denied educational opportunities, experiencing lower self-esteem, being subjected to emotional and physical neglect, facing restrictions on social interactions, and being pressured into early marriage or domestic roles. These effects can have long-term impacts on their psychological well-being and economic independence.

content.question: What does the Constitution say with regard to equality? Why do you think it is important for all people to be equal?
content.answer: The Constitution of India guarantees equality to all its citizens under Article 14, which ensures that the state shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India. It is important for all people to be equal to ensure social justice and harmony, prevent discrimination, and promote equal opportunities for all individuals, regardless of their background.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Discuss what you could do if a friend begins to tease a classmate because he is poor.
content.answer: You could talk to your friend privately and explain why teasing someone for being poor is wrong. Encourage understanding and empathy by discussing how everyone deserves respect regardless of their economic status.

content.question: Discuss what you could do if you are watching TV with your family and one of them makes a prejudicial comment about a particular religious community.
content.answer: You could calmly explain why such comments are harmful and promote stereotypes. Encourage a discussion about the importance of respecting all communities and the value of diversity.

content.question: Discuss what you could do if children in your class refuse to share their food with a particular person because they think she is dirty.
content.answer: You could talk to your classmates about why it's important to include everyone and not judge others based on appearances. Encourage them to share and be kind to everyone.

content.question: Discuss what you could do if someone tells you a joke that makes fun of a community because of their accent.
content.answer: You could explain why making fun of someone’s accent is disrespectful and reinforces negative stereotypes. Encourage respectful communication and appreciation for linguistic diversity.

content.question: Discuss what you could do if some boys make remarks about girls not being able to play games as well as them.
content.answer: You could challenge these remarks by highlighting examples of girls excelling in sports. Promote the idea that ability is not determined by gender and everyone should be given equal opportunities.

content.question: Discuss in class what the different groups have suggested for the above situations, and also talk about the problems that can come up when raising the issue.
content.answer: In class, discuss the different suggestions made by groups for handling these situations. Talk about potential challenges, such as resistance from peers or misunderstanding, and how to address them constructively.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

content.question: What are the three components of a map?
content.answer: The three components of a map are distance, direction, and symbol.

content.question: What are the four cardinal directions?
content.answer: The four cardinal directions are North, South, East, and West.

content.question: What do you mean by the term ‘the scale of the map’?

rubrics.title: Defines the scale of a map accurately
Explains the purpose of scale in maps

content.answer: The scale of a map is the ratio between the distance on the map and the actual distance on the ground.

content.question: How are maps more helpful than a globe?

rubrics.title: Explains at least two advantages of maps over globes

content.answer: Maps are more helpful than a globe because they can show more details and are easier to carry.

content.question: Distinguish between a map and a plan.
content.answer: A map is a representation of the Earth’s surface or a part of it, while a plan is a detailed drawing of a small area on a large scale.

content.question: Which map provides detailed information?

rubrics.title: Identifies the correct type of map

content.answer: A thematic map provides detailed information.

content.question: How do symbols help in reading maps?

rubrics.title: Explains the purpose of symbols in maps

content.answer: Symbols help in reading maps by representing different features like roads, rivers, and cities. They make maps easier to understand.

worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

Draw a plan of your classroom and show the teacher’s table, blackboard, desks, door and windows.
content.answer: A correctly drawn classroom plan should include all specified elements: teacher’s table, blackboard, desks, door, and windows, accurately placed and proportionally represented with clear labels or symbols.

content.question: Draw a sketch of your school and locate the following: the principal’s room, your classroom, the playground, the library, some big trees, and drinking water.
content.answer: A correctly drawn sketch map of the school showing the principal’s room, classroom, playground, library, some big trees, and drinking water, with clear labels and appropriate symbols.

content.question: Make the plan of a fun-park where you can enjoy several activities: for example swings, slides, see-saw, merry-go-round, boating, swimming, looking into funny mirrors, etc., or anything else that you can think of.

rubrics.title: Creativity and Originality

rubrics.title: Logical Layout

rubrics.title: Use of Space
rubrics.description: Effective use of space is demonstrated, with activities well-distributed across the park.

rubrics.title: Clarity of Presentation
rubrics.description: The plan is clearly presented, with labels and legends where necessary.

content.answer: A detailed drawing of a fun-park plan including all specified activities, creatively arranged, with a logical layout and clear presentation.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Look at the newspaper headlines above and list the different kinds of activities that the government is reported to be doing in these newspaper headlines.
content.answer: The government is involved in activities such as implementing policies, maintaining law and order, providing public services, and managing the economy.

content.question: Isn’t this a wide range of activities? What do you think government is? Discuss in class.
content.answer: The government is an organization that is responsible for creating and enforcing laws, providing public services, protecting citizens, and managing the country's resources and economy.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Can you list three things that the government does which have not been mentioned.
content.answer: Examples of government functions that may not have been mentioned include: regulating trade and commerce, providing public education, and maintaining public parks and recreation facilities.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: What do you understand by the word ‘government’? List five ways in which you think the government affects your daily life.

rubrics.title: Impact on Daily Life - Law and Order

content.answer: Government is the system or group of people governing an organized community, often a state. It affects daily life through education policies, healthcare services, infrastructure development, law enforcement, and economic regulations.

content.question: Why do you think the government needs to make rules for everyone in the form of laws?
content.answer: The government makes laws to maintain order, protect individual rights, and prevent chaos in society.

content.question: Name two essential features of a democratic government.
content.answer: Two essential features of a democratic government are free and fair elections and the rule of law.

content.question: What was the suffrage movement? What did it accomplish?
content.answer: The suffrage movement was a decades-long fight to win the right to vote for women. It accomplished granting women the right to vote.

content.question: Gandhiji strongly believed that every adult in India should be given the right to vote. However, a few people don’t share his views. They feel that illiterate people, who are mainly poor, should not be given the right to vote. What do you think? Do you think this would be a form of discrimination? Give five points to support your view and share these with the class.
content.answer: Denying voting rights based on literacy is discriminatory. All adults should have equal voting rights to ensure representation, empowerment, and social justice.

content.question: What problem did the villagers in Hardas village face? What did they do to solve this problem?
content.answer: The villagers in Hardas village faced the problem of water scarcity. To solve this problem, they decided to construct a tank and deepen the existing wells. The Panchayati Raj played a crucial role in organizing the community and mobilizing resources for these projects.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: What, in your opinion, is the importance of the Gram Sabha? Do you think all members should attend Gram Sabha meetings? Why?
content.answer: The Gram Sabha is important because it is the primary body of the Panchayati Raj system and ensures direct participation of the people in decision-making. It is crucial for transparency and accountability in governance. All members should attend Gram Sabha meetings to ensure their voices are heard and to contribute to the development of their community. Participation helps in the effective functioning of the Gram Sabha and ensures that decisions reflect the collective will of the people.

content.question: What is the link between a Gram Sabha and a Gram Panchayat?
content.answer: The Gram Sabha is a body comprising all the adult members of a village or a group of villages. It is the foundation of the Panchayati Raj system and acts as a forum for discussing local issues and making decisions. The Gram Panchayat, on the other hand, is the executive body elected by the Gram Sabha to implement its decisions and manage local governance. The Gram Sabha provides directives and oversight, while the Gram Panchayat executes these directives, ensuring accountability and transparency in local governance.

content.question: Take an example of any one task done by a Panchayat in your area/nearby rural area and find out the following: Why it was taken up, where the money came from, and whether or not the work has been completed.
content.answer: Students should provide a specific example of a task undertaken by the Panchayat, such as road construction or water supply improvement. They should explain why the task was necessary, identify the source of funding (e.g., government grants, local taxes), and state whether the task has been completed.

content.question: What is the difference between a Gram Sabha and a Gram Panchayat?

rubrics.title: Comparison between Gram Sabha and Gram Panchayat

content.answer: The Gram Sabha is a body consisting of all the registered voters in the village. It is the decision-making assembly that approves the annual budget and audits the accounts of the Gram Panchayat. The Gram Panchayat, on the other hand, is the executive committee elected by the Gram Sabha to implement its decisions and manage the day-to-day affairs of the village.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Why was Bhagvan beaten?
content.answer: Bhagvan was beaten because of a dispute related to land or social injustice, reflecting the issues addressed by the Panchayati Raj system in resolving local conflicts and ensuring justice.

content.question: Do you think that the above is a case of discrimination? Why?
content.answer: Yes, it is a case of discrimination as Bhagvan was treated unfairly due to social hierarchies or biases, which the Panchayati Raj aims to mitigate by promoting equality and justice at the local level.

content.question: Find out more about watershed development and how it benefits an area?
content.answer: Watershed development involves the conservation, regeneration, and judicious use of all the resources — natural (land, water, plants, animals) and human within a watershed. Its benefits include improved water availability, increased agricultural productivity, and enhanced biodiversity. By managing water resources effectively, watershed development can lead to sustainable development and improve the quality of life for local communities.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: What is the work of the police?

rubrics.title: Mention of law and order maintenance

content.answer: The work of the police includes maintaining law and order, preventing crime, and ensuring the safety of citizens.

content.question: List two things that the work of a Patwari includes.
content.answer: The work of a Patwari includes measuring land and keeping land records.

content.question: What is the work of a tehsildar?
content.answer: The work of a tehsildar includes overseeing the collection of land revenue and ensuring the smooth functioning of the tehsil.

content.question: What issue is the poem trying to raise? Do you think this is an important issue? Why?

rubrics.title: Identification of the issue in the poem

content.answer: The poem raises the issue of environmental conservation. It is important because it affects the sustainability of our planet.

content.question: In what ways are the work of the Panchayat, that you read about in the previous chapter, and the work of the Patwari related to each other?
content.answer: The Panchayat is responsible for the administration of the village, while the Patwari maintains land records. Both work together to manage land-related issues in the village.

content.question: Visit a police station and find out the work that the police have to do to prevent crime and maintain law and order in their area especially during festivals, public meetings etc.
content.answer: The police work to prevent crime by patrolling, monitoring public gatherings, and coordinating with community leaders during festivals and public meetings.

content.question: Who is in charge of all the police stations in a district? Find out.

rubrics.title: Correct identification of district police head

content.answer: The Superintendent of Police (SP) is in charge of all the police stations in a district.

content.question: How do women benefit under the new law?

rubrics.title: Understanding of legal benefits for women

content.answer: Under the new law, women benefit from equal rights in property inheritance and protection against domestic violence.

content.question: In your neighbourhood are there women who own property? How did they acquire it?
content.answer: Yes, there are women who own property in my neighborhood. They acquired it through inheritance or purchase.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: List the public services in the village/area such as: the milk society, the fair price shop, the bank, the police station, the agricultural society for seeds and fertiliser, the post office or sub post office, the anganwadi, crèche, government school/s, health centre or government hospital etc. Collect information on three public services and discuss with your teacher how improvements can be made in their functioning. One example has been worked out.

rubrics.title: Collection of Information on Three Services

content.answer: Students should list public services such as the milk society, fair price shop, bank, police station, agricultural society, post office, anganwadi, crèche, government school, and health centre. They should collect detailed information on three of these services, discuss potential improvements with their teacher, and ensure the information is relevant to their local area.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Who owns the land south of Mohan’s field?
content.answer: The land south of Mohan’s field is owned by Raghu.

content.question: Mark the common boundary between Mohan’s and Raghu’s lands.

diagrams.url: The Khasra record of the Patwari gives you information regarding the map given below.

content.answer: The common boundary is the line dividing Mohan’s field from Raghu’s field as depicted in the Khasra map.

content.question: Who can use field no 3?
content.answer: Field no 3 can be used by the community as it is designated as common land.

content.question: What information can one get for field no 2 and field no 3?
content.answer: Field no 2 is owned by Mohan and is used for agriculture. Field no 3 is common land used by the community.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Why did the children go to Yasmin Khala’s house?
content.answer: The children went to Yasmin Khala's house to learn about the functioning of the Municipal Corporation and to understand how it affects their lives.

content.question: List four ways in which the work of the Municipal Corporation affects the life of a city-dweller.
content.answer: The Municipal Corporation affects city-dwellers by providing water supply, maintaining roads, ensuring waste management, and offering public health services.

content.question: Who is a Municipal Councillor?
content.answer: A Municipal Councillor is an elected representative responsible for making decisions and policies for the local municipal area.

content.question: What did Gangabai do and why?
content.answer: Gangabai organized a protest to demand better waste management services from the Municipal Corporation because the garbage was not being collected regularly.

content.question: How does the Municipal Corporation earn the money to do its work?
content.answer: The Municipal Corporation earns money through property taxes, grants from the government, and fees for services like water and sanitation.

content.question: In the two photographs you see different ways of collecting and disposing garbage. Which way do you think provides safety to the person disposing garbage? What are the dangers of collecting garbage in the manner shown in the first photograph? Why do you think that proper ways of disposing garbage are not available to those who work in municipalities?
content.answer: Mechanical methods provide safety as they reduce direct contact with waste. Manual collection poses health risks like infections. Proper methods may not be available due to lack of funds or priority in municipalities.

content.question: Several poor people in the city work as domestic servants as well as work for the Corporation, keeping the city clean. Yet the slums in which they live are quite filthy. This is because these slums seldom have any water and sanitation facilities. The reason often given by the Municipal Corporation is that the land in which the poor have set up their homes does not belong to them and that slum-dwellers do not pay taxes. However people living in middle class neighbourhoods pay very little in taxes compared to the amount of money the corporation spends on them in setting up parks, street lighting facilities, regular garbage collection etc. Also as you read in this chapter, the property taxes collected by the Municipality makes up only 25-30 per cent of its money. Why do you think it is important that the Corporation should spend more money on slum localities? Why is it important that the Municipal Corporation provide the poor in the city with the same facilities that the rich get?
content.answer: It is important to spend on slum areas to ensure social equity and improve living conditions. Providing equal facilities can enhance public health and economic productivity.

content.question: The Government of India launched the Swachh Bharat Mission on 2 October 2014 to promote cleanliness in both rural and urban areas all over the nation. Under the “Swachh Bharat, Swachh Vidyalaya” campaign, many activities are also being carried out in schools to generate awareness on sanitation and hygiene amongst students. Observe the ways in which “Swachh Bharat Abhiyan” is being implemented by municipality / panchayat in your locality. Prepare a poster and display it in your school.
content.answer: A poster illustrating local Swachh Bharat activities, highlighting cleanliness drives, and promoting hygiene awareness.

content.question: In the two photographs you see different ways of collecting and disposing garbage.
content.answer: Labels should accurately identify manual and mechanical waste collection methods.

content.question: Look at the image related to the Swachh Bharat Mission.
content.answer: Labels should highlight key components of the Swachh Bharat Mission depicted in the image.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

The city is divided into several

five years for the panchayat as well as for the municipality.
While the councillors make decisions the administrative staff led by the Commissioner

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Describe the work that you see people doing in the above pictures.
content.answer: The pictures depict various activities such as farming, cattle rearing, and handicrafts, which are common in rural areas. These activities are crucial for the livelihood of people in rural communities.

content.question: Identify the different types of work that are related to farming and those that are not. List these in a table.
content.answer: Farming-related work includes plowing, sowing, and harvesting. Non-farming work includes pottery, weaving, and shopkeeping. The table should clearly separate these activities into two columns.

content.question: In your notebook draw some pictures of work that you have seen people do in rural areas and write a few sentences that describe the work.
content.answer: Drawings may include activities such as farming, fishing, or pottery. Descriptions should accurately reflect the work shown and connect it to the livelihood of rural communities.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Why do both Sekar’s and Aruna’s families have to borrow? What similarities and differences do you find?
content.answer: Sekar's family borrows money to buy seeds and fertilizers for farming, while Aruna's family borrows to repair their fishing nets and boat. Both families borrow due to financial constraints and unpredictable income. The similarity is that both rely on natural resources for livelihood, while the difference lies in their occupations: farming versus fishing.

content.question: Have you heard of tsunami? What is this and what damage do you think it might have done to the life of fishing families like Aruna’s?

rubrics.title: Understanding of Impact on Fishing Families

content.answer: A tsunami is a series of large ocean waves caused by underwater earthquakes or volcanic eruptions. It can devastate coastal areas, destroying homes, boats, and fishing equipment, leading to loss of livelihood for fishing families like Aruna’s.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: You have probably noticed that people in Kalpattu are engaged in a variety of non-farm work. List five of these.
content.answer: The people in Kalpattu engage in activities such as pottery, basket weaving, blacksmithing, carpentry, and tailoring.

content.question: List the different types of people you read about in Kalpattu who depend on farming. Who is the poorest among them and why?

rubrics.title: Identifies the poorest and provides reasoning

content.answer: In Kalpattu, small farmers, landless laborers, and tenant farmers depend on farming. The poorest are often the landless laborers because they do not own land and rely solely on daily wages.

content.question: Imagine you are a member of a fishing family and you are discussing whether to take a loan from the bank for an engine. What would you say?

rubrics.title: Considers pros of taking a loan
Considers cons of taking a loan

content.answer: Taking a loan could help increase our catch and income, but the risk is high if we cannot repay. We should consider our current financial situation and potential income increase before deciding.

content.question: Poor rural labourers like Thulasi often do not have access to good medical facilities, good schools, and other resources. You have read about inequality in the first unit of this text. The difference between her and Ramalingam is one of inequality. Do you think this is a fair situation? What do you think can be done? Discuss in class.
content.answer: The situation is unfair as it limits opportunities for people like Thulasi. The government could provide better access to education and healthcare to reduce inequality.

content.question: What do you think the government can do to help farmers like Sekar when they get into debt? Discuss.
content.answer: The government can provide low-interest loans, subsidies for seeds and fertilizers, and implement debt relief programs to help farmers like Sekar.

content.question:
Compare the situation of Sekar and Ramalingam by filling out the following table:

SEKAR

Land cultivated

Labour required

Loans required

Selling of harvest

Other work done by them

RAMALINGAM
content.answer: Sekar: Small land, requires family labor, often takes loans, sells to local markets, does odd jobs. Ramalingam: Larger land, hires labor, less reliant on loans, sells to wholesalers, involved in business.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Describe the work that Thulasi does. How is it different from the work Raman does?
content.answer: Thulasi works as an agricultural laborer, performing tasks such as planting, weeding, and harvesting crops. Raman, on the other hand, owns some land and hires laborers to work on it. Unlike Thulasi, Raman's work involves managing the farm and making decisions about crop production.

content.question: Thulasi gets paid very little money for the work she does. Why do you think agricultural labourers like her are forced to accept low wages?
content.answer: Agricultural laborers like Thulasi accept low wages due to a lack of alternative employment opportunities, high competition for jobs, and the seasonal nature of agricultural work. Additionally, they may lack bargaining power and education, which limits their ability to demand higher wages.

content.question: In what ways would her way of earning a living have been different if Thulasi owned some farm land? Discuss.
content.answer: If Thulasi owned some farmland, she would have more control over her work and income. She could decide what crops to grow and potentially earn more by selling produce directly. Ownership would also provide economic independence and reduce reliance on low-paying labor jobs.

content.question: What are the crops grown in your region or nearby rural area? What kinds of work do agricultural labourers do?
content.answer: In my region, common crops include rice, wheat, and sugarcane. Agricultural laborers engage in activities such as sowing seeds, watering plants, applying fertilizers, and harvesting crops. They also help in maintaining the fields and handling post-harvest tasks.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: What do you see in this illustration?
content.answer: The illustration depicts various urban livelihoods such as street vendors, shopkeepers, and service providers. It shows a busy city scene with people engaged in different occupations.

content.question: You have already read about the work that people do in rural areas. Now compare the work that people in this illustration are doing with the work that people do in rural areas.
content.answer: In rural areas, people often engage in agriculture, livestock rearing, and cottage industries. In contrast, the illustration shows urban livelihoods such as retail, services, and transportation. Urban jobs are more diverse and service-oriented compared to the agricultural focus in rural areas.

content.question: Some parts of the city are different from others. What differences do you notice in this illustration?
content.answer: The illustration might show differences such as residential areas, commercial zones, and industrial sections. It could depict varying levels of infrastructure, density, and types of businesses, highlighting the diversity within urban settings.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Why did Bachchu Manjhi come to the city?
content.answer: Bachchu Manjhi came to the city in search of better livelihood opportunities, as rural areas often lack sufficient employment options.

content.question: Why can’t Bachchu Manjhi live with his family?
content.answer: Bachchu Manjhi cannot live with his family due to economic constraints and the high cost of living in the city, which makes it difficult to afford adequate housing for his entire family.

content.question: Talk to a vegetable vendor or hawker and find out how do they organise their work, their way of preparing, purchasing, selling etc.
content.answer: Vendors typically start their day early, purchasing fresh produce from wholesale markets. They organize their stalls to attract customers, set competitive prices, and ensure quality to maintain regular clientele.

content.question: Bachchu Manjhi has to think twice before taking a day off from work. Why?
content.answer: Bachchu Manjhi has to think twice before taking a day off because he is a daily wage earner, and missing a day of work means losing a day's income, which directly affects his ability to meet daily expenses.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Why did Harpreet and Vandana start a showroom? What do they have to do to run the showroom?
content.answer: Harpreet and Vandana started a showroom to expand their business and reach more customers. To run the showroom, they need to manage inventory, hire staff, and ensure customer satisfaction.

content.question: Talk to a shop owner in a market and find out how he plans his work. Have there been any changes in his business in the past twenty years?
content.answer: The shop owner plans his work by stocking up on popular items and offering discounts during festive seasons. Over the past twenty years, changes include the adoption of digital payment methods and online marketing.

content.question: What are the differences between those who sell on the street and those in the market?
content.answer: Street vendors often have lower costs and more flexibility but face challenges like weather and lack of permanent space. Market sellers have a fixed location and better infrastructure but incur higher costs.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Why do you think small workshops and factories employ casual workers?
content.answer: Small workshops and factories employ casual workers because it allows them to reduce costs by paying lower wages and not providing benefits. Casual employment offers flexibility to employers to adjust the workforce according to demand.

content.question: Describe the working conditions of people like Nirmala keeping in mind the following: working hours, conditions in the workplace, earnings, and the days of work available.
content.answer: People like Nirmala often work long hours in poor conditions with inadequate facilities. They earn low wages and have irregular workdays, depending on the availability of work.

content.question: Would you say that domestic workers like housemaids are also casual workers? Why? Describe the workday of one such woman detailing the work she does in other peoples’ houses.

rubrics.title: Identification of Domestic Workers as Casual

content.answer: Yes, domestic workers like housemaids are considered casual workers because they often work without formal contracts and have irregular hours. A typical workday involves cleaning, cooking, and other household chores in multiple houses.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Complete the following table and discuss how their work is different.
content.answer: The table should include different types of urban workers such as street vendors, office workers, and factory workers. Discuss differences in terms of job security, income, and working conditions.

content.question: In what ways is a permanent and regular job different from a casual job? Discuss.
content.answer: A permanent job offers job security, regular income, and benefits like health insurance, while a casual job lacks these and is often temporary with irregular income.

content.question: What benefits does Sudha get along with her salary?
content.answer: Sudha receives benefits such as health insurance, paid leave, and retirement benefits along with her salary.

content.question: Fill in the following table to show the services provided by people in the markets which you visit frequently.
content.answer: The table should list services such as grocery vendors, clothing shops, and food stalls, highlighting the diversity of services available in urban markets.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: What did Patrick think his cat was playing with? What was it really?

rubrics.title: Identifies what Patrick thought the cat was playing with
Correctly identifies what it really was

content.answer: Patrick thought his cat was playing with a little doll. It was actually a little man, an elf.

content.question: Why did the little man grant Patrick a wish?

rubrics.title: Explains the reason why the little man granted a wish

content.answer: The little man granted Patrick a wish because Patrick saved him from the cat.

content.question: What was Patrick’s wish?
content.answer: Patrick's wish was for the little man to do all his homework until the end of the semester.

content.question: In what subjects did the little man need help, to do Patrick’s homework?

rubrics.title: Lists the subjects the little man needed help with

content.answer: The little man needed help with English, Maths, and History.

content.question: How did Patrick help him?

rubrics.title: Describes how Patrick helped the little man

content.answer: Patrick helped the little man by looking up words in the dictionary, guiding him in Maths, and reading books to him.

content.question: Who do you think did Patrick’s homework — the little man, or Patrick himself? Give reasons for your answer.

rubrics.title: Provides a clear opinion on who did the homework
Gives logical reasons to support the opinion

content.answer: Patrick himself did the homework because he ended up doing all the research and learning while helping the little man.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: In the story, Patrick does difficult things he hates to do because the elf pretends he needs help. Have you ever done something difficult or frightening by pretending about it in some way? Tell your classmates about it.
content.answer: Students should describe a personal experience where they faced a challenge or fear by pretending or using imagination to overcome it.

content.question: Say what you feel about homework. Do you think it is useful, even though you may not like it? Form pairs, and speak to each other. Use words and phrases like 'not be fond of', 'not take to', 'not develop a liking for', 'not appeal to', 'not be keen on', 'not have a taste for', 'support', 'assist with', 'the aid of', 'help', 'be a boon', 'give a boost to' to express your thoughts.
content.answer: Students should articulate their thoughts on homework, discussing its usefulness and using the provided phrases to express their opinions.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: This story has a lot of rhyming words, as a poem does. Can you write out some parts of it like a poem, so that the rhymes come at the end of separate lines? For example: Patrick never did homework. 'Too boring,' he said. He played baseball and hockey and Nintendo instead.
content.answer: Students should identify rhyming words from the text and structure them in a poetic format, ensuring that rhymes appear at the end of lines.

content.question: Rewrite the following incomplete sentences carefully, so that the reader does not have to guess what is left out: 1. more and more books 2. too difficult 3. got up late, missed the bus 4. solved the mystery
content.answer: 1. He read more and more books to improve his knowledge. 2. The math problem was too difficult for him to solve. 3. He got up late and missed the bus to school. 4. The detective solved the mystery after gathering all the clues.

content.question: Look at this cartoon by R.K.Laxman. Read the sentence given below the cartoon. Discuss the following questions with your partner: What is it about? Do you find it funny? If so, why? Do you think a cartoon is a serious drawing? Why or why not?
content.answer: Students should analyze the cartoon, identify the humorous elements, and discuss whether cartoons serve as serious commentary or just entertainment.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question:
Do you agree with what the poet says? Talk to your partner and complete these sentences.
(i) A house is made of —————————————————––——— .
(ii) It has ————————————————————————————— .
(iii) A home is made by —————————————————––——— .
(iv) It has —————————————––——————————————— .
content.answer:
(i) A house is made of bricks and beams.
(ii) It has walls, a roof, and windows.
(iii) A home is made by love and care.
(iv) It has warmth, happiness, and family.

content.question:
Now complete these sentences about your house and home.
(i) My house is —————————————————––———————
—————————————————––—————————————— .
(ii) The best thing about my home is ————————————––——
—————————————————––—————————————— .
content.answer:
(i) My house is a place with four walls and a roof. It is located in a quiet neighborhood.
(ii) The best thing about my home is the sense of love and comfort it provides.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: How the Dog Found Himself a New Master!

content.question: Why did the dog feel the need for a master?
content.answer: The dog felt the need for a master because he was tired of wandering about by himself looking for food and being frightened of stronger animals.

content.question: Who did he first choose as his master? Why did he leave that master?
content.answer: The dog first chose the wolf as his master. He left the wolf because he saw that the wolf was afraid of the bear.

content.question: Who did he choose next?
content.answer: The dog chose the bear as his next master.

content.question: Why did he serve the Lion for a long time?
content.answer: The dog served the Lion for a long time because the Lion was the strongest animal in the forest and feared by all others.

content.question: Who did he finally choose as his master and why?

rubrics.title: Understanding the Reason for Final Choice

content.answer: The dog finally chose man as his master because he realized that man was the strongest and the only one who was not afraid of anyone.

worksheet.chapterName: How the Dog Found Himself a New Master!

content.question: Try to make a kite with your friends. Collect the things required such as colour paper/newspaper, thread, glue, a thin stick that can be bent. After making the kite see if you can fly it.
content.answer: Students should gather materials like color paper, thread, glue, and a bendable stick. They should construct the kite by attaching the paper to the stick framework and securing it with glue. The kite should be able to fly, demonstrating understanding of balance and aerodynamics. Students should work together, showing effective collaboration.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Why did Taro run in the direction of the stream?

rubrics.title: Explains the Context of the Stream

content.answer: Taro ran in the direction of the stream because he heard the sound of rushing water and hoped it would lead him to a source of saké, which he wanted to provide for his father.

content.question: How did Taro’s father show his happiness after drinking saké?
content.answer: Taro's father showed his happiness by dancing with joy after drinking the saké, which was a rare treat for him.

content.question: Why did the waterfall give Taro saké and others water?
content.answer: The waterfall gave Taro saké because of his good intentions and desire to help his father, while it gave others water because they were motivated by greed.

content.question: Why did the villagers want to drown Taro?
content.answer: The villagers wanted to drown Taro because they thought he had tricked them into going to the waterfall, where they only found water instead of saké.

content.question: Why did the Emperor reward Taro?
content.answer: The Emperor rewarded Taro for his dedication to his parents and his selflessness, which set a good example for others.

content.question: Taro earned very little money because
options: the price of wood was very low.

content.question: Taro decided to earn extra money
options: to live a more comfortable life.
to buy his old father some saké.
to repair the cracks in the hut.

content.question: The neighbour left Taro’s hut in a hurry because
options: she was delighted with the drink.
she was astonished to hear Taro’s story.
she wanted to tell the whole village about the waterfall.

rewarding Taro with gold and giving the fountain his name.

content.question: Speak the following sentences clearly but as quickly as you can. Learn them by heart: How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck would chuck wood. Betty bought a bit of butter, but the bit of butter was a little bitter so she bought some better butter to make the bitter butter better.
content.answer: Students should focus on clear pronunciation, maintaining a steady pace, and memorizing the sentences accurately.

content.question: The story ‘Taro’s Reward’ shows that Taro is thoughtful, hardworking and also wise. Read aloud the parts of the story that show these qualities in Taro.
content.answer: Students should identify parts of the story where Taro shows thoughtfulness by caring for his parents, hardworking by his dedication to chopping wood, and wisdom by his decision-making skills.

content.question: Like Patrick in the story ‘Who Did Patrick’s Homework’, Taro is helped by magic. Do you believe in magic? What are the magical things that happen in these stories?
content.answer: Students should describe the magical elements in the stories, such as the magical stream in 'Taro's Reward' and the elf in 'Who Did Patrick’s Homework', and express their personal belief in magic.

content.question: Which story do you like better, and why? Do you know such stories in other languages? Discuss these questions in class.
content.answer: Students should articulate their preference for either story with reasons and relate them to similar stories in other languages, if possible.

content.question: Write a paragraph or two about these two stories, comparing them.
content.answer: Students should compare the themes of hard work and magic in both stories, analyze the characters of Taro and Patrick, and conclude with their insights.

1. bed
2. wax
3. fast
4. chop
5. young
content.answer:
1. bed: red, fed
2. wax: tax, max
3. fast: last, past
4. chop: stop, hop
5. young: sung, rung

worksheet.worksheetName: An Indian – American Woman in Space: Kalpana Chawla
worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: An Indian – American Woman in Space: Kalpana Chawla

content.question: Where was Kalpana Chawla born? Why is she called an Indian – American?

rubrics.title: Explains why she is called an Indian-American

content.answer: Kalpana Chawla was born in Karnal, India. She is called an Indian-American because she was born in India and later became a naturalized citizen of the United States.

content.question: When and why did she go to the U.S.? Who did she marry?

rubrics.title: Mentions when Kalpana Chawla went to the U.S.
Explains why she went to the U.S.

content.answer: Kalpana Chawla went to the U.S. in the 1980s for further studies in aerospace engineering. She married Jean-Pierre Harrison.

content.question: How did she become an astronaut? What gave her the idea that she could be an astronaut?

rubrics.title: Describes her journey to becoming an astronaut
Explains what inspired her to become an astronaut

content.answer: Kalpana Chawla became an astronaut by joining NASA after completing her education in aerospace engineering. Her inspiration came from her childhood fascination with flying and space.

content.question: What abilities must an astronaut have, according to the journalist?

rubrics.title: Lists the abilities required for an astronaut

content.answer: According to the journalist, an astronaut must have technical skills, physical fitness, and the ability to work as part of a team.

content.question: Describe Kalpana Chawla’s first mission in space.

rubrics.title: Mentions the duration and key activities of the mission

content.answer: Kalpana Chawla's first mission in space was STS-87 on the Space Shuttle Columbia in 1997. The mission aimed to study the outer atmosphere of the Sun and conduct microgravity experiments. It lasted for 15 days.

content.question: What does Kalpana Chawla say about pursuing a dream? Do you agree with her that success is possible?

rubrics.title: Explains Kalpana Chawla's view on pursuing dreams
Provides a personal opinion on the possibility of success

content.answer: Kalpana Chawla believed that if you have a dream, you should pursue it with dedication and hard work. Yes, I agree with her that success is possible if one is determined and persistent.

worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

pairs.right: a sad accident of a kind that has never happened before in space
a person with the correct qualification to teach people to fly planes
a set of jobs to be done in space by a group
great expertise in a limited field or a particular subject
having knowledge of a wide variety of subjects
something that causes feelings of respect and wonder

rubrics.description: Award 1 point for each correct match between the term and its description.

rubrics.title: Understanding of Terms

worksheet.worksheetName: Use these phrases in sentences of your own
worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: An Indian – American Woman in Space: Kalpana Chawla

content.question: Use the phrase 'broke apart' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: The old bridge broke apart during the storm.

content.question: Use the phrase 'streaked over' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: The meteor streaked over the night sky, leaving a bright trail.

content.question: Use the phrase 'spread across' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: The news of the victory spread across the town quickly.

content.question: Use the phrase 'lifted off' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: The rocket lifted off smoothly from the launch pad.

content.question: Use the phrase 'blast off' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: The spaceship is scheduled to blast off at dawn.

content.question: Use the phrase 'went on' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: Despite the rain, the match went on as planned.

content.question: Use the phrase 'cheered along' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: The crowd cheered along as the parade passed by.

content.question: Use the phrase 'on board' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: Everyone was excited to be on board the new cruise ship.

content.question: Use the phrase 'carry on' in a sentence of your own.
content.answer: She decided to carry on with her studies despite the challenges.
