content.question: Form pairs. Use 'May you...' and 'I wish you/Wishing you' to wish your partner good luck and success in (i) a sports event, (ii) a quiz or a competition, and (iii) a test or examination. Be sure to thank your partner when she/he wishes you in turn.
content.answer: May you succeed in your sports event. I wish you all the best for your quiz. Wishing you great success in your examination. Thank you for wishing me good luck too!

content.question: Look up a telephone directory, or go to a post office, and get a list in English and Hindi of standard phrases that can be sent in greeting telegrams anywhere in India. Discuss which of these you might use, and when. Compare the English and Hindi phrases for expressing good wishes. Do you know such phrases in any other language?

rubrics.title: Comparison of English and Hindi Phrases

content.answer: Standard phrases include 'Best Wishes' and 'Shubhkamnayein'. 'Best Wishes' can be used for general occasions, while 'Shubhkamnayein' is used similarly in Hindi. In Marathi, you might say 'Shubhechha'.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: An Indian – American Woman in Space: Kalpana Chawla

content.question: Do you have a ‘dream’, or something you very much wish to do? Write a paragraph saying what you want or wish to do. Then say (in another paragraph) how you think you can make your dream come true.
content.answer: Students should clearly state their dream or aspiration in the first paragraph and provide a logical and feasible plan to achieve it in the second paragraph. The writing should be coherent and well-structured, using correct grammar and language.

content.question:
Put these sentences from the story in the right order and write them out in a paragraph. Don’t refer to the text.
1. I shall be so glad when today is over.
2. Having a leg tied up and hopping about on a crutch is almost fun, I guess.
3. I don’t think I’ll mind being deaf for a day — at least not much.
4. But being blind is so frightening.
5. Only you must tell me about things.
6. Let’s go for a little walk.
7. The other bad days can’t be half as bad as this.
content.answer: 4. But being blind is so frightening. 1. I shall be so glad when today is over. 7. The other bad days can’t be half as bad as this. 3. I don’t think I’ll mind being deaf for a day — at least not much. 2. Having a leg tied up and hopping about on a crutch is almost fun, I guess. 5. Only you must tell me about things. 6. Let’s go for a little walk.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Why do you think the writer visited Miss Beam’s school?

rubrics.title: Understanding the purpose of the visit

content.answer: The writer visited Miss Beam’s school to understand the unique teaching methods employed there, which focused on empathy and practical learning experiences.

content.question: What was the ‘game’ that every child in the school had to play?
content.answer: The 'game' involved each child experiencing a day of disability, such as being blind or lame, to foster empathy and understanding of challenges faced by differently-abled individuals.

content.question: “Each term every child has one blind day, one lame day…” Complete the line. Which day was the hardest? Why was it the hardest?

rubrics.title: Explanation of why it was the hardest

content.answer: Each term every child has one blind day, one lame day, one deaf day, one injured day, and one dumb day. The blind day was considered the hardest because it required complete reliance on others and heightened other senses.

content.question: What was the purpose of these special days?
content.answer: The purpose of these special days was to teach children empathy and understanding by experiencing the challenges faced by differently-abled individuals, thereby promoting kindness and support.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Match the words and phrases with their meanings in the box below.

pairs.right: Missing home and family while away
A feeling of reassurance and relaxation

content.question: Re-word these lines from the story: I had heard a great deal about Miss Beam’s school.
content.answer: I had been told a lot about Miss Beam's school.

content.question: Re-word these lines from the story: Miss Beam was all that I had expected — middle-aged, full of authority.
content.answer: Miss Beam was exactly as I had imagined — middle-aged and authoritative.

content.question: Re-word these lines from the story: I went to the window which overlooked a large garden.
content.answer: I approached the window that had a view of a large garden.

content.question: Re-word these lines from the story: “We cannot bandage the children’s mouths, so they really have to exercise their will-power.”
content.answer: We can't cover the children's mouths, so they must practice self-control.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Given below is a page from a dictionary. Look at it carefully and find a word which means the same as ghastly. Write down the word and its two meanings.
content.answer: The word that means the same as 'ghastly' is 'horrible'. Meanings: 1) Causing horror; terrifying. 2) Extremely unpleasant.

content.question: Given below is a page from a dictionary. Look at it carefully and find a word meaning a part of the school year.
content.answer: The word is 'term'. It means a fixed period of time during which students attend school.

content.question: Given below is a page from a dictionary. Look at it carefully and find a word that means examination.
content.answer: The word is 'test'. It refers to a procedure intended to establish the quality, performance, or reliability of something, especially before it is taken into widespread use.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Why does the poet want to know where the teachers go at four o’clock?
content.answer: The poet is curious about the lives of teachers beyond school hours, wondering if they are like other people.

content.question: What are the things normal people do that the poet talks about?
content.answer: The poet mentions activities such as coming home, washing socks, and watching TV.

content.question: What does the poet imagine about where teachers live, what they do at home, the people with whom they live, and their activities when they were children in school?
content.answer: The poet imagines teachers living in houses, doing household chores, living with families, and having childhood experiences similar to other children.

content.question: Why does the poet wonder if teachers also do things that other people do?
content.answer: The poet wonders this because teachers are often seen in a professional light, and he is curious if they have ordinary lives like everyone else.

content.question: How does the poet plan to find out? What will he do once he finds out?
content.answer: The poet plans to follow a teacher home to observe their life and intends to write a poem about it.

content.question: What do you think the phrase 'punished in the corner' from the poem means?
content.answer: The phrase likely refers to a common punishment for children in school, where they are made to stand in the corner as a form of discipline.

content.question: What do you think the phrase 'leave their greens' from the poem means?
content.answer: The phrase suggests that children often avoid eating green vegetables, which are considered healthy but not always liked by them.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Peter’s favourite day of the week is Sunday because —————–——————————————— ——————————————————————————–—

rubrics.title: Provides reason related to chapter context

content.answer: Peter’s favourite day of the week is Sunday because he can spend the whole day with his family.

content.question: Nasir wants to learn —————————————— ———————————————————————————— ———————————————————————––––––––
content.answer: Nasir wants to learn how to preserve seeds so that they can be used again.

content.question: Dolma believes that she can make a good Prime Minister because ——————————— ————————————————————————––— ———–————–––————––————––————––

rubrics.title: Explains reasoning related to leadership qualities

content.answer: Dolma believes that she can make a good Prime Minister because she wants to make things better for everyone and help people.

Nasir lives in the city.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Write a paragraph about yourself so that people who read it will get to know you better. You could write about yourself from any point of view, or choose one of the following topics: What I enjoy doing most, What makes me angry, What I hate to do, What I want to become. Remember to give a reason or details of what you write about, so that anyone reading it will understand you better.
content.answer: Students should write a paragraph that clearly expresses their thoughts and feelings about a chosen topic, providing reasons or details to enhance understanding.

content.question: After you have finished your paragraph, affix your photo on the sheet and display it on the wall.
content.answer: Students should attach their photo to their written paragraph and display it as instructed.

content.question: Read each other’s paragraphs. Did you understand someone else better after you had read what he/she wrote?
content.answer: Students should reflect on their understanding of a peer after reading their paragraph, noting any new insights gained.

with words that everyone can play.

content.question: In groups of four discuss the following lines and their meanings: All that you do is match the words to the brightest thoughts in your head.
content.answer: The line suggests that expressing one's thoughts clearly and effectively requires matching words with one's best ideas. 'Brightest thoughts' refer to the most insightful or creative ideas one has.

content.question: In groups of four discuss the following lines and their meanings: For many of the loveliest things have never yet been said.
content.answer: The line implies that there are many beautiful and profound ideas that have not been expressed yet. 'Loveliest things' could refer to thoughts or feelings that have the potential to inspire or move others.

content.question: In groups of four discuss the following lines and their meanings: And everyone’s longing today to hear some fresh and beautiful thing.
content.answer: This line suggests that people have a desire to hear new and inspiring ideas or expressions. 'Fresh and beautiful thing' refers to novel and aesthetically pleasing expressions or ideas.

content.question: In groups of four discuss the following lines and their meanings: But only words can free a thought from its prison behind your eyes.
content.answer: The line indicates that thoughts are trapped in the mind until they are expressed through words. 'Prison behind your eyes' symbolizes the mind, and words are the means to express and share those thoughts.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: "Then the situation changed." What is being referred to?
content.answer: The situation refers to the change in Jumman's attitude towards his aunt after he received her property.

content.question: When Jumman’s aunt realised that she was not welcome in his house, what arrangement did she suggest?

rubrics.title: Explanation of the reason for the arrangement

content.answer: Jumman’s aunt suggested that she be given a monthly allowance to set up a separate kitchen.

content.question: What was the villagers’ reaction when the aunt explained her case to them?
content.answer: The villagers were sympathetic but hesitant to interfere in Jumman's family matters.

content.question: Why was Jumman happy over Algu’s nomination as head Panch?

rubrics.title: Explanation of the reason for Jumman's happiness

content.answer: Jumman was happy because he believed Algu, his friend, would favor him.

content.question: "God lives in the heart of the Panch." the aunt said. What did she mean?
content.answer: The aunt meant that the Panch should be fair and just, as their decision is like God's verdict.

content.question: What was Algu’s verdict as head Panch? How did Jumman take it?
content.answer: Algu's verdict was in favor of the aunt, and Jumman was shocked and felt betrayed.

content.question: Algu found himself in a tight spot. What was his problem?
content.answer: Algu was in a tight spot because he had to choose between friendship and justice.

content.question: Why was Algu upset over Jumman’s nomination as head Panch?

rubrics.title: Explanation of the reason for Algu's upset

content.answer: Algu was upset because he feared Jumman might seek revenge for the previous verdict.

content.question: What was Jumman’s verdict as head Panch? How did Algu take it?
content.answer: Jumman's verdict was fair and just, which surprised Algu and restored their friendship.

content.question: Which of the following sums up the story best? Give a reason for your choice.
options: "I also know that you will not kill your conscience for the sake of friendship."
"Let no one deviate from the path of justice and truth for friendship or enmity."
"The voice of the Panch is the voice of God."

worksheet.subject: English

content.question:
Look at the following picture. One asks a question, the other answers it. Then the answer is noted in a form as shown below.
Questions Yes/No Additional Response
1. Do you like to meet people? Yes I do, but not always. I do have some close friends, though.
2. Do you like the area you live in? No, I don’t. But I have no choice.
content.answer: The answer should reflect a clear understanding of the dialogue, provide a coherent and relevant response to the questions asked, and include any additional information or reasoning if applicable.

content.question: Work in small groups. Ask your partner the questions given below. If possible, ask him/her a reason for saying Yes or No. Then tick Yes/No, whichever is proper.
content.text:
1. Do you have a separate room for sleep and study?
2. Would you prefer to live in a joint family?
3. Do you get on with people?
4. Do you like the area you live in?
5. Do you find the place overcrowded?
6. Do you use public transport?
7. Would you like a vehicle of your own?
8. Do you like reading?
9. Would you like to be a teacher/doctor/engineer/architect?
content.answer: Students should actively participate in the group activity, provide reasons for their Yes/No answers, and engage with their peers' responses.

content.question: Now that you have completed the above project, write a brief report stating what you did, how you did it and the conclusion.
content.answer: The report should clearly explain the steps taken during the project, describe the process in detail, and present a logical conclusion based on the findings.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Who is the speaker in the poem? Who are the people the speaker meets? What are they doing?
content.answer: The speaker in the poem is a child. The child meets a hawker, a gardener, and a watchman. The hawker is selling bangles, the gardener is digging the ground, and the watchman is walking up and down the street.

content.question: What wishes does the child in the poem make? Why does the child want to be a hawker, a gardener, or a watchman? Pick out the lines in each stanza, which tell us this.
content.answer: The child wishes to be a hawker, a gardener, and a watchman because they seem to have freedom. The lines are: 'I wish I were a hawker, spending my day in the road, crying, 'Bangles, crystal bangles!''; 'I wish I were a gardener, digging away at the garden with nobody to stop me from digging.'; 'I wish I were a watchman walking the street all night.'

content.question: From the way the child envies the hawker, the gardener, and the watchman, we can guess that there are many things the child has to do, or must not do. Make a list of the do’s and don’ts that the child doesn’t like. The first line is done for you. The child must come home at a fixed time. The child must not get his clothes dirty in the dust. Now add to the list your own complaints about the things you have to do, or must not do.
content.answer: The child must not play outside after dark. The child must finish homework before playing. The child must not eat too many sweets. Personal complaints may vary.

content.question: Like the child in the poem, you perhaps have your own wishes for yourself. Talk to your friend, using 'I wish I were...'
content.answer: I wish I were a bird, flying freely in the sky. I wish I were a musician, playing beautiful music.

content.question: Find out the different kinds of work done by the people in your neighbourhood. Make different cards for different kinds of work. You can make the card colourful with pictures of the persons doing the work.
content.answer: Examples of jobs include: teacher, shopkeeper, doctor, plumber. Cards should include a drawing of each person doing their job.

content.question:
“It was to be a battle of champions.”
(i) What qualities did the two champions have? Pick out words and phrases from the paragraph above this line in the text and write them down.
Mongoose Cobra
(a) ________________ (a) ________________
(b) ________________ (b) ________________
(c) ________________ (c) ________________
content.answer: Mongoose: (a) Clever, (b) Aggressive, (c) Swift; Cobra: (a) Skillful, (b) Strong, (c) Alert

content.question: What did the cobra and the mongoose do, to show their readiness for the fight?
content.answer: The cobra spread its hood and hissed, while the mongoose bushed its tail and stood on its hind legs.

content.question: Who were the other two spectators? What did they do? (Did they watch, or did they join in the fight?)
content.answer: The other two spectators were a myna and a crow. They watched the fight but did not join in.

content.question:
Read the descriptions below of what the snake did and what the mongoose did. Arrange their actions in the proper order.
(i) ceased to struggle l grabbed the snake by the snout
(ii) tried to mesmerise l dragged the snake into the mongoose the bushes
(iii) coiled itself around l darted away and bit the the mongoose cobra on the back
(iv) struck the crow l pretended to attack the cobra on one side
(v) struck again and l refused to look into the missed snake’s eyes
(vi) struck on the side l sprang aside, jumped in that the mongoose and bit pretended to attack
content.answer: Snake: (iii), (ii), (iv), (v), (vi), (i); Mongoose: (iv), (vi), (v), (iii), (ii), (i)

content.question:
(i) What happened to the crow in the end?
(ii) What did the myna do finally?
content.answer: (i) The crow was struck by the cobra and fell dead. (ii) The myna flew away to safety.

content.question: The word ‘round’ usually means a kind of shape. What is its meaning in the story?
content.answer: In the story, 'round' refers to a period or session, such as a round of visits or rounds of applause.

content.question:
Find five words in the following paragraph, which are generally associated with trees. But here, they have been used differently. Underline the words.

Hari leaves for work at nine every morning. He works in the local branch of the firm of which his uncle is the owner. Hari’s success is really the fruit of his own labour. He is happy, but he has a small problem. The root cause of his problem is a stray dog near his office. The dog welcomes Hari with a loud bark every day.
content.answer: The words are 'leaves', 'branch', 'fruit', 'root', and 'bark'.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: Honeysuckle - Textbook in English for Class VI

content.question: Suppose Dehra Dun is 300 years old. How old is the tree?
content.answer: The tree is as old as Dehra Dun, which is 300 years old.

content.question: Use the words in the box to speak about the people and the things below, using as...as or -er than.
content.answer: Example: The book is as interesting as the movie.

content.question: Heights: Compare the heights using as...as or -er than.
content.text:
Zeba (155cm)
Ruby (150cm)
Rani (155cm)
answers: Zeba is as tall as Rani

content.question: Weight Lifters: Compare the weights using as...as or -er than.
content.text:
Vijay (50kg)
Akshay (50kg)
Anwar (65kg)
answers: Vijay is as heavy as Akshay

content.question: City Temperatures: Compare the temperatures using as...as or -er than.
content.text:
Shimla (60)
Gangtok (60)
Srinagar (20)
answers: Shimla is as cold as Gangtok

content.question: Lengths: Compare the lengths using as...as or -er than.
content.text:
Romi’s pencil (3 inches long)
Mona’s pencil (5 inches long)
Raja’s pencil (3 inches long)
answers: Romi's pencil is as long as Raja's pencil
Mona's pencil is longer than Romi's pencil
Mona's pencil is longer than Raja's pencil

content.question: City Temperatures: Compare the temperatures using as...as or -er than.
content.text:
Delhi (430)
Chennai (390)
Nagpur (430)
answers: Delhi is as hot as Nagpur

content.question: Read again the paragraphs of the story in which the author describes the banyan tree, and what he used to do there. Is there a place in your house, or in your grandparents’ or uncles’ or aunts’ houses, that you specially like? Write a short paragraph about it, saying where it is, what you do there, and why you like it. You may instead write about a place you dislike, or are afraid of.
content.answer: The answer should include a description of a place the student likes or dislikes, activities they do there, personal feelings about the place, and a connection to the theme of the banyan tree in the story.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: A Pact with the Sun - Supplementary Reader in English for Class VI

content.question: How did the two baby birds get separated?
content.answer: The two baby birds got separated due to a storm that blew them away to different places.

content.question: Where did each of them find a home?
content.answer: One bird found a home near a cave where robbers lived, and the other near a rishi's ashram.

content.question: What did the first bird say to the stranger?
content.answer: The first bird said, 'Quick! Hurry up! There's someone under the tree. Come and take his jewels and his horse.'

content.question: What did the second bird say to him?
content.answer: The second bird said, 'Welcome to the ashram. Please go inside and make yourself comfortable. The rishi will be back soon.'

content.question: How did the rishi explain the different ways in which the birds behaved?
content.answer: The rishi explained that the birds behaved differently because they were influenced by the company they kept.

content.question: Which one of the following sums up the story best?
options: A bird in hand is worth two in the bush.
One is known by the company one keeps.
A friend in need is a friend indeed.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: A Pact with the Sun - Supplementary Reader in English for Class VI

content.question: Why did the farmer bring a baby mongoose into the house?
content.answer: The farmer brought a baby mongoose into the house to have a companion for his child and to protect the household.

content.question: Why didn’t the farmer’s wife want to leave the baby alone with the mongoose?
content.answer: The farmer’s wife was afraid that the mongoose might harm the baby, as it was an animal and could not be fully trusted.

content.question: What was the farmer’s comment on his wife’s fears?
content.answer: The farmer reassured his wife that the mongoose was harmless and would not hurt the baby.

content.question: Why did the farmer’s wife strike the mongoose with her basket?
content.answer: The farmer’s wife struck the mongoose with her basket because she saw blood on its mouth and assumed it had harmed her baby.

content.question: Did she repent her hasty action? How does she show her repentance?
content.answer: Yes, she repented her hasty action after realizing the mongoose had actually saved her baby from a snake. She was filled with regret and sorrow for her actions.

content.question: Do you have a pet — a cat or a dog? If not, would you like one? How would you look after it? Are you for or against keeping birds in a cage as pets?
content.answer: This question requires a personal response. Students should reflect on their own experiences or desires regarding pet ownership, describe how they would care for a pet, and express their opinion on keeping birds in cages.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: A Pact with the Sun - Supplementary Reader in English for Class VI

content.question: The shepherd hadn’t been to school because
options: there were very few schools in those days.

content.question: Who visited the shepherd one day, and why?
content.answer: The king visited the shepherd to test his wisdom and humility.

content.question: Why did the other governors grow jealous of the shepherd?
content.answer: The other governors grew jealous of the shepherd because he was loved and respected by the people for his wisdom and fairness.

content.question: Why was the new governor called to the palace?
content.answer: The new governor was called to the palace to prove his loyalty and integrity.

content.question: Why was everyone delighted to see the iron chest on the camel’s back?
content.answer: Everyone was delighted because they thought the chest contained treasures, but it actually symbolized the shepherd's honesty.

content.question: What did the iron chest contain? Why did the shepherd always carry it? Is it an example of the shepherd’s humility or wisdom or both?
content.answer: The iron chest contained only an old blanket. The shepherd always carried it as a reminder of his humble beginnings. It is an example of both his humility and wisdom.

content.question: How did the king reward the new governor?
content.answer: The king rewarded the new governor by making him the governor of a much larger province.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: A Pact with the Sun - Supplementary Reader in English for Class VI

content.question: Why did Swami Haridas say Tansen was ‘talented’?
content.answer: Swami Haridas said Tansen was talented because he could mimic the sounds of birds and animals perfectly, showing his natural musical ability.

content.question: Why did Akbar ask Tansen to join his court?
content.answer: Akbar asked Tansen to join his court because he was impressed by Tansen's singing talent and wanted him to be one of his nine jewels.

content.question: How do we know that Akbar was fond of Tansen? Give two reasons.
content.answer: Akbar was fond of Tansen because he often praised his singing and gave him valuable gifts as a token of appreciation.

content.question: What did the other courtiers feel about Tansen?
content.answer: The other courtiers were jealous of Tansen's talent and the attention he received from Akbar.

content.question: What happens if Raga Deepak is sung properly? Why did Tansen’s enemies want him to sing the Raga?
content.answer: If Raga Deepak is sung properly, it can create fire. Tansen's enemies wanted him to sing it to harm him, as they knew it could cause him to burn.

content.question: Why did Tansen agree to sing Raga Deepak?
content.answer: Tansen agreed to sing Raga Deepak because he felt compelled to prove his skill and because he was challenged by his enemies.

content.question: What steps did he take to save himself? Did his plan work? How?
content.answer: Tansen taught his daughter to sing Raga Megh, which brings rain, to counteract the effects of Raga Deepak. His plan worked as the rain cooled the fire.

content.question: Are you interested in music? Do you like classical music? Name a few distinguished Indian musicians.
content.answer: Responses will vary. Some distinguished Indian musicians include Ravi Shankar, Lata Mangeshkar, and Zakir Hussain.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: A Pact with the Sun - Supplementary Reader in English for Class VI

content.question: The monkey was happy living in the fruit tree, but his happiness was not complete. What did he miss?
content.answer: The monkey missed having a friend to talk to and share his life with.

content.question: What did the two friends generally talk about?
content.answer: The two friends, the monkey and the crocodile, generally talked about their lives, the monkey's life in the tree, and the crocodile's life in the river.

content.question: Why was the crocodile’s wife annoyed with her husband one day?
content.answer: The crocodile's wife was annoyed because she wanted to eat the monkey's heart and her husband had not brought the monkey to her.

content.question: Why was the crocodile unwilling to invite his friend home?
content.answer: The crocodile was unwilling to invite his friend home because he knew his wife wanted to eat the monkey's heart.

content.question: What did the crocodile tell the monkey midstream?
content.answer: The crocodile told the monkey midstream that he was taking him to his wife because she wanted to eat the monkey's heart.

content.question: How did the monkey save himself?
content.answer: The monkey saved himself by telling the crocodile that he had left his heart on the tree and needed to go back to get it.

content.question: What does the last sentence of the story suggest? What would the crocodile tell his wife?
content.answer: The last sentence suggests that the crocodile realized his mistake. He would tell his wife that he lost the monkey's friendship due to her greed.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: A Pact with the Sun - Supplementary Reader in English for Class VI

content.question: What is the most obvious advantage of sleep?
content.answer: The most obvious advantage of sleep is that it helps our body to rest and recover, allowing us to feel refreshed and energized.

content.question: What happens to our body when we sleep?
content.answer: When we sleep, our body undergoes various processes such as repair and growth, consolidation of memories, and restoration of energy.

content.question: Define a dream in your own words.
content.answer: A dream is a series of thoughts, images, or emotions occurring during sleep, often reflecting our subconscious mind.

content.question: Why are dreams important? Mention two reasons.
content.answer: Dreams are important because they can help process emotions and experiences, and they can also inspire creativity and problem-solving.

content.question: Why has sleep been called a wonder?
content.answer: Sleep is called a wonder because it is essential for maintaining physical and mental health, and it allows the body and mind to rejuvenate.

content.question: Describe briefly to the class an improbable dream you have ever had.
content.answer: An improbable dream I had was flying over a city made of candy, where I met talking animals and had a conversation with a wise owl.

content.question: Grandmothers and mothers sing nice little songs while rocking little ones to sleep. Such a song is called a ‘lullaby’. Do you remember a lullaby in your own language? Tell the class in English what the lullaby says.
content.answer: A lullaby I remember is about a mother singing to her child about the stars and the moon, wishing them sweet dreams and peaceful sleep.

worksheet.subject: English
worksheet.book: NCERT: A Pact with the Sun - Supplementary Reader in English for Class VI

content.question: What did the physicians ask Saeeda’s mother to do to get well? Did their advice help her? If not, why?
content.answer: The physicians asked Saeeda’s mother to stay in a dark room with doors and windows closed, avoiding fresh air and sunshine. Their advice did not help her as she continued to be unwell due to the lack of fresh air and sunlight, which are essential for recovery.

content.question: What did the specialist prescribe in addition to medicine?
content.answer: The specialist prescribed effective medicine and advised Saeeda’s mother to sit in the sun every morning from eight to nine and to have fresh air, as these were more important than medicine.

content.question: What did Saeeda tell the sunrays to do?
content.answer: Saeeda requested the sunrays to come the next day with lots of warmth and brightness to help her mother get well.

content.question: Why were the sunrays keen to go down to the earth the next day?
content.answer: The sunrays were keen to go down to earth because they had promised Saeeda that they would help her mother by providing warmth and brightness.

content.question: What is your own formula for keeping good health?
content.answer: A balanced diet, regular exercise, adequate sleep, and spending time in sunlight are essential for good health.

content.question: Who would you recommend to a patient in your neighbourhood — the physicians contacted first or the specialist contacted next? Give reasons for your choice.
content.answer: I would recommend the specialist as he provided a holistic approach to health, emphasizing the importance of sunlight and fresh air along with medicine.

content.question: When would you make a pact with the sun? When you are going on a picnic, or when you are playing a cricket match? Think of other occasions.
content.answer: I would make a pact with the sun when planning an outdoor event, like a picnic or a cricket match, to ensure good weather. Other occasions could include a wedding or a garden party.

worksheet.subject: Civics
worksheet.book: NCERT: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE – I - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Identify which level the decision belongs to and place tick marks against the level you consider most appropriate.
content.text:
Local
State
Central

questions.answer: Each decision should be matched with the correct level of government: Local, State, or Central.

content.question: The decision of the Government of India to maintain peaceful relations with Russia.

questions.answer: This decision is taken by the Central Government as it involves foreign policy, which is a central subject.

content.question: The decision of the Government of West Bengal on whether to have Board exam in Class 8 for all government schools.

questions.answer: This decision is taken by the State Government as education is a state subject in India.

content.question: Introduction of two new trains between Dibrugarh and Kanyakumari.

questions.answer: This decision is taken by the Central Government as railways are a central subject.

content.question: The decision to locate a common well in a particular area of the village.

questions.answer: This decision is taken by the Local Government as it involves community resources.

content.question: Decision to construct a big children’s park in Patna.

questions.answer: This decision is taken by the Local Government as it involves urban development within a city.

content.question: The decision of the Government of Haryana to provide free electricity for all farmers.

questions.answer: This decision is taken by the State Government as it involves state-level agricultural policy.

content.question: Introduction of a new 1000 rupee note.

questions.answer: This decision is taken by the Central Government as it involves monetary policy.
